author: Dean Arcuri
title: After 20 years, Canberra's Cube Nightclub is closing its doors
text: After 20 years, Cube Nightclub, which helped define Canberra's nightlife and LGBTQIA+ culture, is closing its doors. It's the final countdown for Cube Nightclub in Canberra, which will close its doors at the end of 2025. \"Hospitality in Canberra is probably at its worst point in my time,\" Venue manager and drag queen Seth Byrnes told Canberra Times. \"People don't have the money to spend on going out as much.\" \"It's stuff out of our control, cost-of-living crisis, the work's going on in the light rail, a combination of things.\" Taking to social media this week, the announcement that \"the final season of Cube is here\" \"After 20 unforgettable years, Cube Nightclub will be closing its doors at the end of this year,\" they said on Instagram. \"This isn\u2019t just a farewell to a venue, it\u2019s the close of an era that helped define Canberra\u2019s nightlife and LGBTQIA+ culture.\" \"For over two decades, Cube has been more than a club, it\u2019s been a sanctuary, a celebration, and a second home. \"From the artists to the staff, the drag royalty to the DJs, the lovers, the misfits, the first-timers and the faithful regulars, \"Every one of you shaped what Cube became. \"Together, we created something unforgettable.\" View this post on Instagram A post shared by Cube Nightclub (@cubecanberra) 'Cube's a gay nightclub and if you don't like it, F&^K off!' Attending Cube for 17 years, Douglas Robinson shared some of his thoughts and memories about the club. \"Cube's a gay nightclub and if you don't like it, F&^K off!\" \"More than anything else, I remember Morris, the former owner of Cube, saying these words over the microphone, \"Every single weekend, I was clubbing in my teens and early twenties. \"With Cube being the only gay Nightclub in the city and really the only safe space at that time. \"Hearing those words was a reassurance that this place was a home. \"I've spent time at Cube as a patron, a drag queen, and a photographer. \"Have met people I've lived with, people I've dated and lifelong friends. \"Have seen more drag queens and performers grace the stage, \"From the local, to interstate, to international drag race stars, then I could think to count or name. \"I remember the legendary theme nights and people dressing up to win costume contests and prizes, \"And the club being so full, the line extended down the block. \"Cube is a club older than the new queers experiencing it for the first time. \"That's an incredible legacy for a venue. \"My visits get less as I get older, but I wouldn't change a thing about the memories and experiences I've had there over the years.\" Source: Douglas Robinson A LGBTQ+ haven for many over the years Cube is one of the oldest clubs in Canberra and one of the only gay and lesbian venues in the capital for many years. The venue was a haven for many when it opened. \"There were less venues that were welcoming of being queer,\" Byrne said, \"Now, fortunately, being gay is a bit more of an open thing, and people are a lot more comfortable with it.\" \"Cube used to be that one-off safe space compared to what else was available in the city.\" Many took to social media, sharing memories of Cube when hearing the news. \"I always felt safe there to be ourselves & was treated like family.\" posted Kaya McKay, who also worked the door for a while. \"Cube was the first gay bar I ever went to, and in a roundabout way, it helped me out of the closet.\" Damien Victorsen wrote, \"Party nights at Cube helped me find my way to the amazing LGBTIQ+ community in New York City, where I now live.\" Nadine Howton, who ran Cube from 2006 to 2012, responded to the announcement. \"I am devastated to hear this.\" \"This is our safe space, our baby we grew from the ground up.\" \"So many memories! I met my wife there!! \"As Morris just said to me, they can take our club, but they can\u2019t take our memories!! \"All my cube family - let\u2019s organise a 'last dance' and see the old gal off as she deserves!\" Photo by Douglas Robinson Let's give Cube the send-off it deserves. Byrne cited rising hospitality costs, declining drink sales, light rail works and changes in habits that led to the decision. Like many venues across the country, COVID lockdowns have played a factor in changes to patron attendance. Young people missed out on their first clubbing experiences while older and regular patrons got out of the habit. What was a part of people's weekly routine and connection has now changed. But though things have changed over the years, Byrnes says the heart of Cube lives on. \"The pureness of Cube is that if you still go to a dance floor on a Saturday night,\" \"There are still not that many phones and stuff out.\" \"It's still people having fun and being in the moment.\" Byrnes is working hard to make the final months of Cube a celebration of its iconic 20 years. \"Bringing back a lot of performers, a lot of drags,\" \"A lot of obscure dancing kind of things that Cube can have in here,\" \"Some old staff members, some people who just made the place feel like a community at home,\" he said. As Cube prepares to say goodbye at the end of the year, they have promised not to go quietly. \"In the months ahead, we\u2019ll be revisiting some of Cube\u2019s most iconic events,\" they said on Instagram. \"Bringing back the energy, the sparkle, and the community that made it all so special.\" \"With a stacked lineup of our favourite DJs, drag performers, and creators, we\u2019ll be celebrating the legacy of Cube, \"Loud, proud, and together. \"Let\u2019s give Cube the send-off it deserves.\" Photos by Douglas Robinson For the latest LGBTIQA+\u00a0Sister Girl and Brother Boy\u00a0news,\u00a0entertainment,\u00a0community stories\u00a0in Australia, visit\u00a0qnews.com.au. Find us on\u00a0Facebook,\u00a0Twitter,\u00a0Instagram\u00a0and\u00a0YouTube.

author: Consolato Cicciù
title: A Reggio Calabria la 3ª edizione di Marinai Solidali: ospite l’atleta Aurora Esabotini
text:
Sabato 21 settembre salpano i Marinai Solidali per la veleggiata realizzata come ogni estate dall’ANMI di Reggio Calabria per costruire una rete tra associazioni a sostegno delle fasce deboli della popolazione. La collaborazione tra i Marinai d’Italia dei Gruppi di Reggio Calabria e di Villa San Giovanni e il Cip Calabria Comitato Italiano Paralimpico in questa terza edizione costruisce un nuovo binomio che darà frutti in altri successivi incontri e non si fermerà a questa attività della Veleggiata davanti alle coste di Scilla, meravigliosa meta mitologica oltre che turistica ma proporrà alternative.
Special Guest di questa 3ª edizione è l’atleta Aurora Esabotini, giovane e promettente artista del Nuoto. Aurora è già Campionessa nazionale dei 50 metri dorso ai campionati italiani. All’anniversario della sua vittoria, rilascia l’intervista e diventa testimonial d’eccellenza nella costruzione di questa operazione solidale. Il suo percorso di riorganizzazione degli allenamenti c’è l’impegno per raggiungere la Medaglia a Los Angeles nel 2028. La tenacia e la dedizione in ogni nuova sfida, a sostegno dell’iniziativa sociale e di formazione dei giovani a scuola. La incontriamo in una intervista che dimostra la concreta costruzione di azioni sul valore del Volontariato. ( Intervista a seguire )
Anche questa volta i protagonisti sono i ragazzi Aurora, Giulia, Federico ed altri che hanno un grande beneficio dalla pratica sportiva della vela anche in questa occasione solidale di scambio sociale. I Marinai Solidali affiancano le persone che desiderano avvicinarsi alla navigazione da diporto, donando se stessi ed il proprio tempo libero; s’impegnano a organizzare le occasioni per vivere insieme in mare, nei porti e sulle imbarcazioni a vela; dedicano un sorriso agli altri per creare relazioni interpersonali in particolare con chi ha più bisogno a partire dai Soci ANMI e a seguire tutti coloro che amano le coste e l’ambiente marino.
Emozione ed empatia in campo come in navigazione a vela sono la risorsa per catalizzare energie nel gruppo: un valido equipaggio è quello in cui ciascuno dona ciò che ha. “La volontà dell’ANMI è di praticare la cittadinanza attiva e di navigare in sicurezza, di affiancare i giovani e i meno giovani in difficoltà, di tessere su tutto il territorio nazionale la “rete del mare”, creando “nodi” come soltanto i marinai sanno fare, issando le vele della solidarietà. anmi.reggiocalabria@gmail.com
Le emozioni dell’atleta L’ANMI di Reggio Calabria lancia con grande interesse l’intervista all’atleta Aurora Esabotini come madrina della terza edizione di Marinai Solidali. La storia breve ma intensa di Aurora comincia nel 2013, anno in cui avvia la sua pratica sportiva. Nuota dapprima con il solo interesse riabilitativo, date le sue condizioni fisiche, poi come impegno per la vita, collezionando medaglie su medaglie.
Un primo risultato che non potrà mai essere dimenticato da Aurora è stato il record del 2021 durante i campionati italiani autunnali sui 50 metri dorso: un’inaspettata vittoria che mai si sarebbe immaginata un risultato così importante. Anno per anno la passione per questo sport si è consolidata, diventando una ragione della sua stessa esistenza. La certezza dei risultati non per caso, ma con un lavoro studiato e dettagliato, frutto di tecniche ed ore illimitate di allenamenti. Dietro e dentro di me- dice Aurora- non c’è solamente la determinazione e la volontà di affermarmi come atleta, ma pure una famiglia attenta che mi dà supporto e sostegno come d’altronde fa il mio ragazzo. Il suo sogno nel cassetto è quello di poter entrare a far parte della nazionale paralimpica e di partecipare alle prossime Paralimpiadi che si terranno a Los Angeles nel 2028.
La Presidente del gruppo dell’ANMI di Reggio Calabria Sabrina Martorano parla con lei per far conoscere quanta vita c’è dietro un sogno di vittoria e quante sofferenze dentro ogni successo. Qual è oggi la tua priorità? “Parlare di priorità mi sembra riduttivo, direi quali sono le cose che mi rendono felice. Nonostante siano tanti i motivi che mi appagano, scelgo la passione che mi fa alzare presto il mattino e mi rende orgogliosa di me stessa sempre”.

author: Peter Kimani
title: Baba's quest for power and glory in Addis will only end with tears without teargas - The Standard
text: Opposition leader Raila Odinga aka Baba is back in the news as the nation readies to offer his candidature as the next chair of the African Union. And the big debate is whether he is a State project or not. The bigger story is that Baba has been scammed big time to even consider this quest. Here’s the thing: it might look regal and statesmanlike for him to receive presidents and guide them to their seats, dine and wine with them and have chase cars with blaring sirens when he rides through gridlocked traffic, but that will be the limits of his power. Baba’s real power resides in the people - the base that he galvanises as no one ever does, or possibly ever will - and who hang on his every word as though it were the law. So, if he declared tomorrow a public holiday, then tomorrow shall be a public holiday, and it doesn’t need a gazette notice to be effected. I hear even those that voted for “the other side” are asking for his intervention, apparently because things are only getting thicker, and they are keen on getting their disaffection registered on national platforms, the sort that Baba represents. That’s the power that made Baba’s opponents who hire crowds quake in their boots because it’s scary, quite honestly, to have any one individual wielding so much power. So, we need to know whose idea it was to remove Baba from the trenches and cast him into boardrooms where he is seen, not heard, a fitting metaphor for the eclipsing that awaits. And whether he secures the seat of not, Baba’s goose is cooked. If he doesn’t clinch the seat and returns to the trenches, he will be cast as a sore loser. And if he clinches it and quickly changes his mind, after recognising he was given short shrift to return to local politics, the stigma of having been a State “project” will stick. That could potentially whittle his influence, while providing a distraction from local political scene that sorely needs his energy and mobilising skills.
